title: Étude No. 1

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on pressboard.

description: Widely considered Georges Vantongerloo’s first abstract painting, Étude No. 1 is the culmination of a series of increasingly complex geometric analyses of a seated female figure. Although difficult to discern within the cascades of overlapping circles, a body starts to emerge when we direct our eyes toward the red triangle at bottom. From this sharply pointed toe, legs and torso ascend, rising up along an axis that is also the physical centerline of the painting. Early critics sometimes faulted Vantongerloo for the draft-like or unfinished appearance of his work from this period, alluded to in the picture’s title. But the artist himself admired and sought out this hazy, lightly painted look, where interlocking solids and voids might suggest bodies in a state of perpetual motion.
credit_line: Through prior bequest of Joseph Winterbotham; partial gift of the Goldberg Family
exhibition_history:
Geneva, Exposition internationale d’art moderne, Dec. 26, 1920–Jan. 25, 1921, cat. nos. 129 or 130, as Étude (peinture).

Barcelona, Galerías Dalmau, Exposición de arte moderno nacional y extranjero, Nov. 1929, cat. 37, as Composition étude.

Paris, Galerie Charpentier, Salon des réalités nouvelles, renaissance plastique, 1re exposition (2me série). Oeuvres des artistes étrangers, June 30–July 15, 1939, no cat. no.

Paris, Galerie de Berri, Georges Vantongerloo: exposition 1909–1939, 30 années de recherches, Feb. 13–27, 1943, cat. 4, as Etude, 1917.

Paris, Galerie Maeght, Les premiers maîtres de l’art abstrait, Apr.–June, 1949, cat. 128.

Zürich, Kunsthaus Zürich, Antoine Pevsner, Georges Vantongerloo, Max Bill, 1949, cat. 28, as Etude No. 4, 1917.

New York, Rose Fried Gallery, Georges Vantongerloo, Apr. 14–May 9, 1953, cat. 4, as etude, 1917.

Washington, D.C., Corcoran Gallery of Art, Georges Vantongerloo: A Traveling Retrospective Exhibition, April 22–June 17, 1980, cat. 4, as Study no. I, 1917; Dallas Museum of Fine Arts, July 16–September 14, 1980, Los Angeles County Museum of Art, October 9–December 28, 1980.

Madrid, Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia, Georges Vantongerloo: A Longing for Infinity, Nov. 3, 2009–Feb. 22, 2010, no cat. no., as Étude no. 1, 1917.
provenance_text: The artist [according to the artist's logbook; photocopy in curatorial file]; sold to Lillian Florsheim (1896–1988), Chicago, May 26, 1961 [according to invoice from the artist sent to Florsheim; photocopy in curatorial file]; by descent within the family, Chicago, 1988; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2019.
